Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Taiwan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Patricia Clayton of University of Washington to conduct a research project, entitled "Steel walls for reducing building damage during earthquakes," during the summer of 2012 at the National Center for Research in Earthquake Engineering (NCREE) in Taipei, Taiwan. The host scientist is Dr. K.C. Tsai.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is experimental testing of an innovative steel wall structural system that is designed to recenter itself following an earthquake and remain essentially damage-free, thus greatly reducing the repair costs and downtime in buildings. This research is the first full-scale test of this new wall concept and promises to verify its capability of achieving this improved seismic performance. The experiments consist of subjecting the wall to forces and displacements that a building would experience during different levels of earthquake intensity and recording how the wall responds to these demands. r This research may also result in the development of structural design concepts that can greatly reduce the economic and social impact of earthquakes.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“Steel walls for reducing building damage during earthquakes”

With the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) fellowship, University of Washington Ph.D. student Patricia Clayton travelled to Taipei, Taiwan to conduct research at National Taiwan University (NTU) and the National Center for Research in Earthquake Engineering (NCREE). The topic of her research was experimental testing of a new structural system referred to as a self-centering steel plate shear wall (SC-SPSW) for use in seismically active regions. Current structural systems are designed to save lives and prevent building collapse during strong earthquakes; to do so, the structure may sustain significant damage that can be very difficult and costly to repair or rebuild. The innovative SC-SPSW system has been developed to provide enhanced building performance beyond life safety, including being able to recenter itself following an earthquake and virtually eliminate damage to the beams and columns. This enhanced performance will ultimately reduce loss of building functionality and reduce structural repair costs following a seismic event.

A full-scale two-story SC-SPSW was experimentally tested at NCREE during the duration of the EASPI program. NCREE is one of the few structural laboratories in the world capable of testing specimens of such a large scale. In this test, actuators were used to push the SC-SPSW from side-to-side to simulate the lateral sway that a building would undergo during an earthquake. The SC-SPSW specimen was subjected to three levels of earthquake intensity, including a frequent earthquake, a design-level earthquake, and a maximum considered earthquake. The results of the tests verified that the SC-SPSW was able to meet the intended enhanced performance objectives, including recentering and negligible damage to the beams and columns even after sever shaking, making it a viable structural system for resisting earthquake loads and reducing structural repair costs.

The results of these tests will be disseminated to engineers and researchers through numerous journal publications and presentations at conferences. The data will also be available to the public through the NSF-supported Network for Earthquake Engineering Simulation (NEES) data repository (https://nees.org/warehouse/project/0631).  Practicing engineers may use this information to implement and inform the design of SC-SPSW structures, and having access to the data and experimental results will allow other researchers to further advance research on self-centering technologies and steel plate shear walls for seismic regions.

In addition to the experimental testing at NCREE, the EAPSI program also provided the fellow with first-hand exposure to Taiwan’s social and academic culture.  The connections made with Taiwanese students and researchers during this program will foster international collaboration in the fellow’s future career in academia. Exposure to current structural engineering and experimental testing practices in Taiwan also provided the fellow with broader global awareness and the potential for incorporating these practices into her current and future research in the U.S.
